summary: This is a letter from Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys (Cohen & Gresser LLP) to the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, providing a list of potential defense witnesses for Maxwell's criminal trial. The letter identifies three attorneys whose testimony may involve privilege issues and includes a broader witness list with names like Dr. Park Dietz and Dr. Elizabeth Loftus.

events.title: Court Order on Witness Disclosure
events.description: The Court issued an order (Dkt. 297) regarding procedures for disclosing potential witnesses, which this letter is complying with.

events.title: Defense Witness List Submission
events.description: Maxwell's defense team formally submitted their list of potential witnesses to the U.S. Attorney's Office, as required by court order.

locations: United States Attorney's Office Southern District of New York, 1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
COHEN & GRESSER LLP, 800 Third Avenue, 21st Floor, New York, New York 10022
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team disclosed a list of potential witnesses for her criminal trial, including three attorneys (Brad Edwards, Robert Glassman, and Jack Scarola) whose testimony may involve attorney-client or other privilege issues.

The witness list includes notable expert witnesses like forensic psychiatrist Dr. Park Dietz and memory expert Dr. Elizabeth Loftus, suggesting the defense may challenge victim testimony or psychological aspects of the case.
The disclosure was made pursuant to a court order dated June 2, 2021, and the defense reserved the right to add or substitute witnesses as they further defined their case.
The letter indicates the defense provided a hyperlink to a Sharefile containing disclosures under Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 26.2, which governs the production of witness statements.
The document is a formal communication from defense counsel Christian R. Everdell to the prosecution, outlining procedural steps for witness testimony and potential stipulations.
